intro: Guachamaca, commonly known as the "false holly," is a flowering plant native to the Andean region of South America. It belongs to the family Euphorbiaceae and is characterized by its spiny, woody stems and clusters of small, greenish-yellow flowers. The plant produces bright red berries that are often used in traditional medicine for their purported healing properties. Guachamaca thrives in dry, rocky environments and is adapted to high-altitude conditions. Its unique morphology and ecological role make it an important species in its native habitat.
